ESTIMATED ANNUAL 
ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE OBLIGATIONS 
AT A MEDIUM REFINERY IN THE UNITED STATES 
APRIL 1997 
The attached chart shows an estimate of the environmental compliance obligations that 
a medium refinery in the United States must meet each year. In addition to overall totals, 
data is provided by four main subcategories: 
. Air permit requirements 
l Water permit requirements 
. Release reporting and spill prevention requirements 
. Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) requirements 
The chart was compiled by selecting, for each subcategory, a refinery that appeared to 
be typical in that area and then reviewing the compliance obligations at that facility. 
Refineries with unusual features that would present an atypically high or low number-of.: 
compliance obligations were avoided. The resulting composite is believed to, be; 
representative of a medium-sized refinery of medium complexity, but is not an “average!-

compliance obligations were avoided. The resulting composite is believed to, be; 
representative of a medium-sized refinery of medium complexity, but is not an “average!- 
of data compiled from a representative sample of facilities. Three refineries were 
examined in the course of preparing the chart, but only two refineries are represented in 
the composite data. 
The composite facility employs 564 workers and covers 780 acres. It operates 24 hours_ 
per day and is capable of processing 190,000 barrels per day of oil. It produces a range 
of petroleum products including gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and heating oil. The refinery 
includes 69 storage tanks and can store a total of 6.7 million barrels of crude-oil, 
intermediates, and finished products. It receives crude oil and other raw materials by ship; 
barge, rail, pipeline, and truck, and uses these same methods to transport finished 
products to customers and distribution facilities. The refinery has submitted its Clean Air

barge, rail, pipeline, and truck, and uses these same methods to transport finished 
products to customers and distribution facilities. The refinery has submitted its Clean Air 
Act Title V permit application, has a Clean Water Act NPDES permit with five permitted: 
outfalls, and operates under RCRA Interim Status, having submitted Part A and Part B- 
permit applications. 
In many cases, counting the number of compliance obligations in a given area was 
straightforward; in other cases it required some judgment. For example, where an air 
permit requires compliance with an emission limit for sulfur dioxide on a one-hour average 
basis, this fairly clearly generates 8,760 compliance obligations in a year (assuming that 
the facility operates 24 hours per day, 365 days per year). However, in the case of 
continuous requirements such as the RCRA requirement to maintain adequate aisle space 
in a container storage area or the NPDES requirement to have a certified operator for the-

continuous requirements such as the RCRA requirement to maintain adequate aisle space 
in a container storage area or the NPDES requirement to have a certified operator for the- 
wastewater treatment plant, it is less clear how to count the number of compliance 
obligations imposed on a yearly basis. Depending on what seemed most appropriate in

the particular circumstances, these continuous requirements were counted as either daily 
(365) or annual (1) compliance obligations. 
Another issue concerns requirements that only become applicable if a certain event occurs 
-- for example, the requirement to report a release if one occurs under the appropriate 
circumstances. In these “contingent” situations, the number of events each year that 
would trigger the compliance obligation was estimated based on the facility’s recent- 
history. This estimate was then used to calculate the number of compliance obligations 
that would result. 
The chart is based primarily on requirements that arise pursuant to federal law. Where a. 
state permit or regulation contains a requirement that mirrors a federal requirement, the 
obligation was counted only once even though it arises from two sources of law. 
Furthermore, areas of wholly state, regional, or local regulation were not counted at all.

Examples of compliance obligations not counted toward the total pursuant to this practice-+ 
include those arising under local noise ordinances, state solid waste regulations, and states 
release reporting requirements. Some miscellaneous federal requirements have.beerr 
omitted from the chart as well. 
The chart represents the efforts of ten people working intermittently over a period of about 
four months. In total, about 250 hours were spent developing the information it contains.
